intro: Haplopappus palmeri subsp. typicus, commonly known as the desert groundsel, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and serrated leaves. The plant typically grows in arid and semi-arid environments, showing adaptations to drought and high temperatures. Its small, yellowish flowers are clustered in a single head, and the plant produces achenes with pappus hairs for wind dispersal. It has a low, spreading growth habit and is often found in sandy or gravelly soils.
